importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Naroditsky won the under-12 boys' world youth championship in Antalya, Turkey, marking the beginning of his international recognition in chess.
Naroditsky earned the title of chess grandmaster by winning the 2013 US Junior Championship while still a teenager.
Naroditsky was hired by The New York Times as a chess columnist and contributed to a series of chess puzzles for its games section.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Naroditsky was active in chess content creation and media, particularly through YouTube and Twitch, from 2022 onward, which coincides with his rise as a prominent public figure in digital chess education.
This period marks the peak of Naroditsky's early career achievements, including youth championships and the publication of his first book, establishing him as a rising talent in the chess world.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, a US chess grandmaster and popular YouTube chess commentator, died at the age of 29.
Naroditsky's YouTube channel had nearly 500,000 subscribers, and his Twitch stream had 340,000 followers.
He was praised for making chess accessible and fun, especially for beginners, and was known for his calm demeanor and deep knowledge of chess history and theory.
He inspired hundreds of thousands of people worldwide to play chess, including many who began playing at age 14 or later.
Naroditsky won the under-12 boys' world youth championship in 2007 and earned the grandmaster title in 2013.
He authored a book titled 'Mastering Positional Chess' at age 14.
Naroditsky graduated from Stanford University and worked as a chess coach in Charlotte, North Carolina.
He was a close friend and collaborator with Hikaru Nakamura and Nemo Zhou, both prominent figures in the chess community.
The International Chess Federation acknowledged his pivotal role in popularizing chess content online.
Fans and players described him as a 'true historian of the game' with kindness, passion, and a genuine love for chess.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, a US chess grandmaster and popular online chess commentator, has died at the age of 29. His family and the Charlotte Chess Center announced his unexpected death, with no cause given. Naroditsky was widely admired for his engaging YouTube tutorials and live streams, which reached nearly half a million subscribers and 340,000 Twitch followers. He played a pivotal role in popularizing chess content online, inspiring hundreds of thousands of amateur players worldwide to take up the game. A former youth world champion and author of a book on positional chess at age 14, Naroditsky earned the grandmaster title in 2013 and later worked as a chess coach in Charlotte, North Carolina. He was also a columnist for The New York Times and known for his calm demeanor, deep knowledge of chess history, and passion for teaching. Fellow players and fans, including Hikaru Nakamura and Nemo Zhou, praised him as a kind, insightful, and inspirational figure. His death has prompted widespread tributes, with fans citing his videos as life-changing in their journey into chess.
title: Daniel Naroditsky, US chess grandmaster, dies aged 29
